articles.headline: Companies Bolster Sales Abroad to Offset Weakness at Home
articles.snippet: The success of American firms overseas may help prevent the economy from slipping into a recession.
articles.abstract: The success of American firms overseas may help prevent the economy from slipping into a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALISBURY, N.C., Nov. 16 — If the fortunes of the Power Curbers company were tied solely to business in the United States, these would be grim days at its factory on the fringes of this Piedmont town. The small, family-owned company makes machines that turn concrete into curbs, and with the American construction industry in distress, domestic sales are expected to drop at least 10 percent this year.

articles.headline: New Worries About Credit Drive Down Stock Markets
articles.snippet: An analyst’s downgrading of Citigroup to “sell” hit a raw nerve among investors and sent the Dow tumbling more than 218 points.
articles.abstract: An analyst’s downgrading of Citigroup to “sell” hit a raw nerve among investors and sent the Dow tumbling more than 218 points.

articles.headline: Amway Adds Entertainment to Product Line
articles.snippet: Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, is pouring millions of dollars into a new online store called Fanista, which will initially sell DVDs and CDs.
articles.abstract: Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, is pouring millions of dollars into a new online store called Fanista, which will initially sell DVDs and CDs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 — Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, wants to reinvent how Hollywood sells entertainment.

articles.headline: Baghdad’s Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves
articles.snippet: Iraqis are beginning to reclaim their lost lives five months after extra U.S. troops arrived, but the depth of the changes remains open to question.
articles.abstract: Iraqis are beginning to reclaim their lost lives five months after extra U.S. troops arrived, but the depth of the changes remains open to question.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Nov. 19 — Five months ago, Suhaila al-Aasan lived in an oxygen tank factory with her husband and two sons, convinced that they would never go back to their apartment in Dora, a middle-class neighborhood in southern Baghdad.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: A New Science, at First Blush
articles.snippet: Scientists are working feverishly to develop new technologies to test cosmetics before a European Union ban on animal testing begins in March 2009.
articles.abstract: Scientists are working feverishly to develop new technologies to test cosmetics before a European Union ban on animal testing begins in March 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRASSE, France — The delicate hybrids thriving in the balmy climes of Provence, southern France’s traditional perfume region, include sweet jasmine, May roses — and fresh layers of artificial human skin.

articles.headline: As Somali Crisis Swells, Experts See a Void in Aid
articles.snippet: Somalia has higher malnutrition rates, more current bloodshed and many fewer aid workers than Darfur.
articles.abstract: Somalia has higher malnutrition rates, more current bloodshed and many fewer aid workers than Darfur.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFGOOYE, Somalia, Nov. 19 — The worst humanitarian crisis in Africa may not be unfolding in Darfur, but here, along a 20-mile strip of busted-up asphalt, several top United Nations officials said.

articles.headline: U.N. to Say It Overstated H.I.V. Cases by Millions
articles.snippet: A U.N. agency will lower to 33.2 million the number of people it believes are infected worldwide.
articles.abstract: A U.N. agency will lower to 33.2 million the number of people it believes are infected worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency plans to issue a report today acknowledging that it overestimated the size of the epidemic and that new infections with the deadly virus have been dropping each year since they peaked in the late 1990s.

articles.headline: As U.S. Cools, World Demand Helps H.P. Outpace Rivals
articles.snippet: Buoyed by its presence abroad, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.
articles.abstract: Buoyed by its presence abroad, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 — Buoyed by its heavy international presence, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.
